Tells Gertrude to take care of Richard before walking away alone.
Unenthusiastically talks on the phone about Frank's return, indicating distraction and detachment.
Confidently walks back up the aisle with all eyes on her, owning the situation.
Threatens to destroy Richard's career to force a marriage and takes control of the situation by directing others efficiently (ordering the band, drinks, and Gilbertson).
Calmly hands off the bouquet, maintains composure with all eyes on her, and manages a confident exit despite underlying personal issues.
Appears unenthusiastic and distracted on the phone, indicating possible emotional fatigue or resignation, though still completes necessary communications.
Downplays recent successes (Frank's return) and the significance of the weekend, suggesting a possible lack of optimism or motivational drive at this moment.
Admits the situation is getting too messy and ends the pretense; acknowledges reality honestly.
Encourages Richard to stay with Gertrude, saying they are perfect for each other and it's the right thing.
Acts cold and short to Richard, telling him not to worry about her and that she will survive.
Despite trying to act cold, sincerely wishes Richard an amazing life and compliments him as a good person he deserves happiness.
Denies her emotional reaction when Richard shakes her hand, suppressing her feelings.
Decides to end the complicated situation clearly and honestly by telling Richard that it is over, showing a capacity to make tough decisions and maintain control.
Leaves the sheets intact because she isn't sure about the protocol, showing consideration but also some uncertainty in attention to detail.
Attempts to act cold and controlled despite underlying emotion, demonstrating emotional control and self-restraint.
Avoids prolonging the conversation and downplays her own situation, showing confidence and decisiveness.
Refuses to engage in an awkward or undignified conversation with Mr. Gilbertson, asserting boundaries and self-respect.
Agrees to publish Gilbertson's book under pressure, showing ability to comply strategically even when uncomfortable.
Expresses reluctance and emotional discomfort openly before acquiescing—shows vulnerability that may undermine perceived confidence.
Studies the safety pamphlet quietly, trying to ignore an annoying passenger.
Shakes her head and re-buckles her seat belt when asked to come to the radio, refusing to respond to Richard.
Responds quickly and wittily to Richard's advances and comments with incredulous and sarcastic remarks.
Initially resists emotional vulnerability but shows self-awareness by hesitating to deny Richard's point, indicating internal conflict.
Stops herself from responding immediately, revealing cautiousness and thoughtful internal processing.
Uses terse, dismissive phrases ('What's your point?', 'Is that the best you got?') to maintain control of the conversation.
Remains silent when asked if she is going back to him during a tense moment.
Hands CB radio to the Handsome Man to help resolve disruptive passenger situation.
Blushes modestly after the Handsome Man addresses the passengers and receives their support.
Allows the Handsome Man (Federal Air Marshall) to take control of the situation regarding the disruptive passenger, remaining calm without escalating conflict.
Does not respond to Gilbertson's provocation, showing restraint and composure in a tense situation.
Passively hands over the CB to the Air Marshall, facilitating resolution of the conflict.
Grabs Richard and plants a long, deep, and wet kiss on him, showing affection and spontaneity.
Jokes with Gilbertson about his arrest affecting his work and the cancelled book, displaying wit but a bit of sharpness.
Greets Richard's family warmly and expresses a sincere desire to get to know them and spend time together.
Confidently confronts Gilbertson about his arrest and its consequences on his work and book.
Steps out to face Richard's family with openness and a clear intention to build relationships despite recent events.
Expresses vulnerability and embarrassment about being 'saved', showing self-awareness without losing composure.
Initiates a bold, public, and strategically timed kiss with Richard to demonstrate control over the situation.
Promises Annie that Richard will be happy as long as she is with him.
Shares a big hug with Grandma Annie and others, joining in group affection.
Dances with Richard, both smiling despite not being good dancers.
Promises happiness to Richard and reassures Grandma Annie about the future, showing confidence in her role.
Dances happily with Richard despite not being very skilled, showing confidence and positive attitude.
